image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann looks serious, sitting wearing his glasses against a blurred background.

items.synopsis: The former Liberal Party adviser says his life is "stuffed" and he may never work again after his high-profile rape trial was abandoned.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann says he will seek 'millions' of dollars after inquiry finds prosecution was flawed

image.altText: A woman stands, holding a baby in her hands, looking out a window. The room around her is dark.

items.synopsis: Thousands of babies who've been exposed to their mother's drug use are born in Australia every year. Help is difficult to find.

title.children: Terrianne used ice while pregnant. Now she's breaking a 'vicious cycle'

image.altText: A male student sits at a desk in a mostly empty classroom. Asian calligraphy lines the wall behind him.

items.synopsis: The ACT government is considering running online classes as public school struggle to recruit enough staff to teach foreign languages.

title.children: More Canberra schools are dropping foreign language classes despite being required to teach them

image.altText: Side by side photos of business logos for accounting firms Deloitte, PwC, KPMG and EY

items.synopsis: The infiltration of EY, Deloitte, KPMG and PwC in government departments has been well documented. What is less well known is their role in the private sector, where experts fear a sleeper issue could trigger a corporate collapse, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: How a sleeper issue inside the big four accounting giants could topple the economy

image.altText: A man celebrates after winning a rugby league match

items.synopsis: After 15 seasons and 305 games, Canberra Raiders co-captain Jarrod Croker announces his retirement.

title.children: Canberra Raiders great Jarrod Croker to retire at end of 2023 NRL season

image.altText: A woman with black glasses up against a blue wall

items.synopsis: Mary-Louise McLaws, who was an epidemiologist at UNSW Sydney for more than 35 years and shared crucial information during the pandemic, has died after a long illness, her family has announced.

title.children: Mary-Louise McLaws, renowned epidemiologist who helped guide Australia through the pandemic, dies aged 70

image.altText: A skiier in a yellow jacket skis down a steep slope

items.synopsis: Discretionary spending is money you don't need to spend to keep yourself fed, housed and clothed. What's happening at alpine resorts — remote and relatively expensive — tells us about an important shift in the Australian economy.

title.children: Australians are reducing their spending as the cost of living soars. But that doesn't mean they're making rational choices

image.altText: A composite image of Sam Kerr and Michele Bullock

items.synopsis: From the Matildas to some of the most important appointments in the country, Australian women are beginning to receive the acknowledgement and opportunities at the top of their fields that unquestionably until now have been denied, writes John Lyons.

title.children: What Sam Kerr and new RBA governor Michele Bullock have in common

image.altText: Reza berati

items.synopsis: The 23-year-old was killed in riots at the Australian government's offshore detention centre at Manus Island in 2014.

title.children: Murdered Iranian asylum seeker Reza Berati's parents reach settlement with government, security firm

image.altText: Nicole Hammat holds a framed photograph of her son Khye smiling

items.synopsis: After seeing how quickly her son Khye succumbed to the disease, Nicole Hammat wants young people to be more aware of meningococcal and is pleading for the B strain vaccine to be made accessible to more people.

title.children: Mother's plea for meningococcal B vaccine to be made more accessible as cases continue to rise

image.altText: A woman with curly black hair standing in front of a corrugated wall.

items.synopsis: The first wide-ranging study of sexual violence victims' experiences with the NSW justice system in 27 years will be handed to authorities on Monday.

title.children: How do we make the justice system better for victims? This report offers some solutions

image.altText: Catriona Jackson speaks.

items.synopsis: Leaders at a major Australian university say they have deep concerns around the management of the sector's peak body, Universities Australia (UA).

title.children: Future of Universities Australia head under question over handling of sexual violence concerns

image.altText: Cars are lined up on a road next to a building. The sky is grey and stormy.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Search teams brought in to help locate further victims after Hawaii's devastating fires: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Around the country, people are still celebrating the Tillies' nail-biting win on Saturday as the girls prepare for the semifinal game against England on Wednesday. A stack of venues are being opened up to watch the match: Fans in Brisbane can head to Riverside Green in the South Bank Parklands, with Brisbane's Lord Mayor to add more sites later today Those in Adelaide can head to Festival Plaza Hobart will host a site at Parliament House Lawns Melbourne will host events at Melbourne Rectangular Stadium and Fed Square Fans in Sydey who didn't get a ticket to the match at Stadium Australia can head to Western Sydney Stadium in Parramatta, the Sydney Football Stadium in Moore Park or Tumbalong Park in Darling Harbour Many more smaller suburban sites are also being set up across the country Of course, anyone lucky enough to have a ticket can watch the girls live at Stadium Australia in Sydney. Where will you be watching?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Still got Matildas fever? Here's where you can watch the semifinal

props.alt: Matildas celebrate on field wave to crowd

children.content: (AAP: Darren England)
Around the country, people are still celebrating the Tillies' nail-biting win on Saturday as the girls prepare for the semifinal game against England on Wednesday.
A stack of venues are being opened up to watch the match:
Fans in Brisbane can head to
Riverside Green
in the South Bank Parklands, with Brisbane's Lord Mayor to add more sites later today
Those in Adelaide can head to
Festival Plaza
Hobart will host a site at
Parliament House Lawns
Melbourne will host events at Melbourne
Rectangular Stadium
and
Fed Square
Fans in Sydey who didn't get a ticket to the match at Stadium Australia can head to
Western Sydney Stadium
in Parramatta, the
Sydney Football Stadium
in Moore Park or
Tumbalong Park
in Darling Harbour
Many more smaller suburban sites are also being set up across the country
Of course, anyone lucky enough to have a ticket can watch the girls live at
Stadium Australia
in Sydney.
Where will you be watching?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here is some of this morning's late news: Major university calls for meeting to discuss future of Universities Australia head Catriona Jackson Search teams brought in to help locate further victims of Hawaii fires Pedestrian killed, man in critical condition after Mount Isa, QLD hit-and-run
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to The Loop for Monday, August 14

children.content: Here is some of this morning's late news:
Major university calls for meeting to discuss future of
Universities Australia head Catriona Jackson
Search teams brought in to help locate further victims of
Hawaii fires
Pedestrian killed, man in critical condition after Mount Isa,
QLD hit-and-run

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Extra search teams are being brought in to help locate any further victims of fires that have killed at least 93 people in Hawaii. Specialist crews with cadaver dogs are making their way through what's left of the devastated town of Lahaina but they've only covered a small area so far. The administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Deanne Criswell, says she can't predict how long the operation will take. "We're bringing in more teams and more dogs so we can speed up that process as much as we can." Local authorities fear the death toll could continue to rise as they begin to investigate why residents weren't warned about the fires sooner. Reporting by ABC News's North America correspondent Barbara Miller.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Search teams brought in to help locate further victims of Hawaii fires

props.alt: A pick-up truck on a street surrounded by ash from the wildfires

children.content: The devastation is clear when seen from the air.
(ABC News)
Extra search teams are being brought in to help locate any further victims of fires that have killed at least 93 people in Hawaii.
Specialist crews with cadaver dogs are making their way through what's left of the devastated town of Lahaina but they've only covered a small area so far.
The administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Deanne Criswell, says she can't predict how long the operation will take.
"We're bringing in more teams and more dogs so we can speed up that process as much as we can."
Local authorities fear the death toll could continue to rise as they begin to investigate why residents weren't warned about the fires sooner.
Reporting by ABC News's North America correspondent Barbara Miller.

image.altText: A generic photo of a green seedling in dirt in an egg carton, with other little seedlings around it.

items.synopsis: We heard from more than 1,000 of you who shared the little, and big, things you do to reduce your waste footprint. There were plenty of new and novel ideas for reusing and recycling, so we're tapping into the brains trust.

title.children: We asked for your waste-busting tips. Here are some of your suggestions

image.altText: A man holds two green apples in his hands

items.synopsis: While inflation on food has gone down according to stats from the Australian Bureau of Statistics June 2023 report, prices for things like dairy and bread remain sky high.

title.children: Food prices have risen 7.5 per cent in the last year, here's what that looks like at the check-out

image.altText: a ranger in high viz green suit lights a fire next to a dirt road

items.synopsis: Facing down another potentially dangerous bushfire season, firefighters are warning there is no room for complacency — those at risk need to have a plan.

title.children: The three questions firefighters want you to answer before the next bushfire sparks

image.altText: Australia players look pained after a penalty miss at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: With just four days to recover from their draining penalty shootout win over France, the Matildas are focused on getting their bodies and minds right to face England, rather than drilling tactics.

title.children: Sleeping, eating and hydrating: Four-day turnaround before World Cup semi has Matildas in recovery mode

image.altText: A group of Matildas footballers jump together in delight, celebrating a big win at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The Matildas' move to the semifinals marks the furthest any Australian team has progressed in a World Cup.

title.children: Could a Matilda's World Cup win mean a public holiday for Australians?

image.altText: A man and woman smile for the camera.

items.synopsis: Ian Wilkinson's family says he remains in a critical but stable condition, thanking medical teams and the public for their support after he fell ill in the Victorian town of Leongatha

title.children: Family of man hospitalised after suspected mushroom poisoning thanks medical staff, public for support

image.altText: Two young boys stand out the front of the youth centre.

items.synopsis: In Tennant Creek, where shopfronts are graffitied or boarded up, the town's youth centre stands out as shiny and new — but it's never opened its doors.

title.children: These kids say a youth centre will make a big difference to their lives. One sits empty in their town

image.altText: A police officer crouching down to take a photo of a wrecked car

items.synopsis: If you came across a traffic crash, could you be the difference between life and death?

title.children: Knowing basic first aid could help reduce the road toll —  so should the qualification be part of getting a licence?

image.altText: A man wearing  navy blue jumper and beany smiles at the camera. His beard has a mix of black and grey hair.

items.synopsis: Andrew slept rough on and off for 20 years before he found a job and secure housing eight years ago. Now he's had to access his super to make ends meet.

title.children: Cost of living has almost pushed Andrew back onto the streets while 'fighting very hard' to keep a roof over his head

image.altText: Copy of Thumbnail

items.synopsis: China's president Xi has not visited the places devastated by the two weeks of torrential rain and flooding, which has angered and confused many people.

title.children: While floods ravage northern China, people are wondering — where is President Xi Jinping?

image.altText: Woman drinks from her water bottle looking up towards sun in blue sky.

items.synopsis: If the northern hemisphere's deadly heatwave is anything to go by, Australia could be in for its own long, hot summer.

title.children: More heatwaves are on the horizon and that means more people in hospital

image.altText: A woman wearing an orange polka dot top writes in a notebook in front of a desktop computer

items.synopsis: Can an employer, having first directed you to work from home, now turn around and mandate you don't? Giuseppe Carabetta explains your legal rights.

title.children: Can your employer force you back to the office? Here's what the law says

image.altText: Alex de Minaur clenches his fist and yells during the Canadian Open tennis final.

items.synopsis: Australia's number one goes down to Jannik Sinner in the final of the Canadian Open in Toronto but reaches a new high of 12th in the singles rankings two weeks out from the US Open.

title.children: Aussie Alex de Minaur misses out on first Masters title but climbs to career-high ranking

image.altText: A grey navy patrol ship with a bridge in the background.

items.synopsis: Firing on a merchant vessel is expected to ratchet up already acute concerns among shipowners, insurers and commodity traders about the potential dangers of getting ensnared in the Black Sea.

title.children: Russia fires warnings shots on cargo ship in Black Sea for first time since collapse of UN-brokered grain deal

image.altText: A man crouching in a strawberry field, looking concerned.

items.synopsis: A group of 11 Australian industry organisations has united for the first time, "embarrassed" by a lack of domestic regulation for the word organic, which they argue is deceiving consumers and adding to certification costs for some international markets.

title.children: No regulation of the word 'organic' creates costs for farmers, confusion for consumers

image.altText: Man with red background

items.synopsis: Hip hop helps to create cultural identity and brings together communities, but is still widely seen as an American and African American art form.

title.children: Fifty years on, the Australian hip hop industry still gets a bad rap

image.altText: A young woman stands in an airport with seven medals on red ribbons around her neck.

items.synopsis: After a seven-medal haul at the Commonwealth Youth Games in Trinidad and Tobago, teenage swimmer Inez Miller says she's determined to push for higher honours.

title.children: 'The world's her oyster': Coach hails teenage swimmer after stunning performance at Commonwealth Youth Games

image.altText: A wombat joey sleeps surrounded by a pink blanket.

items.synopsis: Eastern grey kangaroos, wombats, swamp wallabies, and magpies are the top species being caught up in collisions on the roads to Victoria's alpine resorts.

title.children: Calls for drivers to take more care as native wildlife casualties of snow season traffic mount

image.altText: The top five finalists in the 71st Miss Universe pageant in New Orleans, wearing sashes and sparkly dresses.

items.synopsis: The Miss Universe Organisation cuts ties with its Indonesian franchisee and will cancel an upcoming pageant in Malaysia after contestants complained to police, accusing local organisers of sexual harassment.

title.children: Miss Universe cuts ties with Indonesian organiser after allegations of inappropriate 'body checks'

image.altText: Rescue workers stand on a road surrounded by rubble from a mudslide.

items.synopsis: The death toll from a mudslide in China's north-western city of Xian rises to 21, with six people still missing, as China grapples with unusually high summer rainfall.

title.children: Death toll from mudslide near Xian rises to 21 as wet weather wreaks havoc in China

image.altText: A woman wearing a hijab standing near two bookshelves.

items.synopsis: Data shows Melbourne's growth areas have some of the worst access to public libraries across the city, despite being home to some of the youngest populations in the city.

title.children: In a cost-of-living crisis, Melbourne's libraries are a precious resource. But they're not evenly spread

image.altText: A pile of peso banknotes with Star Wars characters painted on them.

items.synopsis: How did a country, once among the wealthiest in the world and uncomfortably similar to Australia, totally lose control of its economy?

title.children: Worthless banknotes and spending money while you have it: This is what life is like with 100pc inflation
